white: Refusing to use the axiom of choice.
Finding a problem too easy and being suspicious.
The ongoing feud between pure and applied mathematics.
Solving the same problem multiple ways.
Trying to find a non-academic job which makes use of pure mathematics.
Saying "Euler" the wrong way for over an hour.
The topological equivalence of a doughnut and a mug.
Being punished by the gods for proving the existence of irrationals.
Working only in fields of characteristic 2.
Claiming a theorem is true because a computer hasn't found a counterexample yet.
Proving general statements in Analysis by drawing pictures of smooth functions.
Writing out the largest known Mersenne prime.
Trying to prove statements which are known to be false.
Being on the wrong tail of a normal distribution.
Working on a problem for several hours before realizing I misread it.
Conceding  that you'd be far more employable if you'd done a Computer Science degree.
Learning a topic purely because the theorems have cool names.
Differentiating everything using the limit definition.
Plotting my love life on a graph.
Being distracted by other, more interesting, mathematics.
Starting at the solution and working backwards.
Assuming that squaring is a linear operation.
Getting so frustrated by a problem that you consider giving up maths forever.
Screwing myself over by only using my intuition.
Getting the right answer the wrong way.
Dara O'Brien's School of Hard Sums.
Being open and closed at the same time.
A compass and a straight edge.
Explaining complex and subtle mathematical concepts inaccurately, using only Youtube videos.
Wasting time on a problem just to realise that it's a trivial application of a big theorem.
Ignoring all rigour and working only with intuition.
Claiming every field is just applied mathematics.
Spending ages on a problem, only to realize that its trivial.
Trying to prove statements about the real numbers by induction.
Being confused by logical inconsistencies in my answers  before realizing I read the question wrong.
Constructing the natural numbers from first principles.
Spending over an hour finding a sign error.
Being stunned when a theorem is proved "properly" in an applied course.
Being secretly relieved when a problem is just a standard application of things you already know.
Being devastated by how ugly a proof is.
Deciding to use a one-tail test at the last minute so your results will be significant.
Making everything trivial by making bad assumptions.
Spending more time learning how to write an xi than actually doing any maths.
Stubbornly sticking to using techniques you were taught in school.
A proof so marvellous that a margin is too narrow to contain it.
Casually engaging in elitist discussions about other areas of mathematics.
Avoiding proving hard theorems by making them axioms.
Leaving it as an exercise to the reader.
Thinking the lecturer made a mistake but, in reality, you're just being stupid.
Pretending to understand an area of maths that you actually know nothing about.
